bestBHT.bht: Jesus instructs his disciples to give alms in secret, for the Father sees what is hidden. Although the addition of Himself in the text is questionable, it is evident that Jesus emphasizes the private nature of these acts. By engaging in good works without ambition, believers can overcome the temptation of vain-glory. God does not require a public display of piety to witness and reward virtuous deeds, as even those performed in darkness can be seen by Him. Prioritizing secret acts of charity before prayer demonstrates their significance in the eyes of God.

John Calvin: He commands his disciples to devote themselves to good works purely, and without any ambition.
He tells them, that God does not need a strong light to perceive good actions: for those things, which appear to be buried in darkness, are open to his view.
A most appropriate remedy is thus applied for curing the disease of ambition, when he reminds us to fix our eye on God: for this banishes from our minds, and will utterly destroy, all vain-glory.

John Gill: There were two chambers in the sanctuary, the one was

לשכת חשאים, 'the chamber of secrets,' and the other the chamber of vessels: the chamber of secrets was that into which pious persons put בחשאי, 'in secret,' and the poor children of good men were maintained out of it privately.
Greater, (say they,) is he that gives alms בסתר, in secret, than Moses our master.
This duty, of giving alms to the poor, is mentioned by Christ before prayer to God; it may be for this reason, because it was usual to give alms before prayer.

bhtAttempts.bht: When giving alms, Jesus instructs his disciples to do so in secret, ensuring that no one sees the act except for the Father who remains hidden from human eyes. While the addition of the word Himself in the text is unsupported, it is clear that Jesus emphasizes the private nature of this act. By doing good works purely and without ambition, believers can escape the trap of vain-glory. This secrecy is deemed essential, as God does not require a prominent show of piety to witness and reward righteous actions. In fact, giving alms is mentioned before prayer, perhaps because it was common practice to give to the poor prior to prayer. By going unnoticed and unnoticed, believers can be confident in their reward from God.
